newsitem.title: BELGIUM: SOCCER-BELGIAN CLUB AALST FACES BRIBERY ALLEGATIONS.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-BELGIAN CLUB AALST FACES BRIBERY ALLEGATIONS.

text.p: Belgian first division club Aalst faces allegations of attempted bribery to fix matches, Belgian soccer union prosecutor Rene Verstringhe said on Friday.
The union's controlling committee, which is considering the allegations, will announce its decision on Tuesday.
Aalst were prominent relegation candidates in late March when they were 17th in the 18-team table, eight points behind 16th-placed Mechelen.
But they staged a remarkable comeback to finish the season two months later in 15th place, five points clear of Mechelen, who were relegated with Cercle Brugge.
Aalst won four of their last six league games and drew the two others. In the previous 28 rounds they had won just four matches and lost 14.
Aalst attributed the turnaround largely to a change of coach earlier this year.

Verstringhe, a leading Belgian lawyer who became prosecutor for the union three years ago, has called for Aalst to be fined up to 1.75 million francs ($49,000) and its manager Patrick Orlans to be suspended for a year.
He also demanded a one-year suspension for a former Aalst youth coach, alleged by players from other clubs who gave evidence to the committee to have acted as an intermediary for Aalst.
"If (the committee) accepts that the club was involved in attempted bribery then it must be relegated, according to the rules," Verstringhe said.
Aalst manager Orlans told BRTN radio he was convinced that charges against the club would be dropped.

"Of course the union prosecutors are our opponents who are claiming a number of things but I still think it is all hardly convincing...there is no direct trace to Aalst, no evidence," Orlans said. ($ = 35.7 Belgian francs)
